SubhÅ«ti said to the Buddha, If there is one who thinks of suffering and happiness, then he does not depart from
suffering and happiness, and this is the two dharmas.

The bodhisattva does not depart from the middle, does not depart from the upper, does not depart from the detached, does not depart from the middle without anything to depart from, and is far from the unconditioned in what he does. This is the arising of what is done like an illusion, using an illusion to free from an illusion, with no illusion in the illusion, and no name in the illusion. In this way, one is not liberated by the Dharma, nor is one liberated by leaving the Dharma. In liberation, there is further liberation. This is having no master but only a name.
In the word, there is no known name. This is the cutting off of the Dharma wheel.
ÅšÄriputra said:
The Dharma wheel is originally pure and non-existent. Who is there to cut off the wheel?
Bao Lai said:
Not knowing where the wheel exists is precisely the cutting off.
The Buddha said:
Those who crave dharmas have the root of birth and death. The extinction of dharmas is also the practice of being without bonds.
The practice of non-action is being without separation from action. Being without craving for various things is precisely being without cutting off.
Being without craving and not arising is precisely the Way. Being without what is acceptable and unacceptable, without birth and non-birth,
without consciousness and non-consciousness, without death and non-death, without cutting off and not cutting off, without distance and not distant, various
things that are acceptable and unacceptable have no thought. Being apart from having no thought, what is contemplated has no thought. What is said
has no saying. Nirvana has no extinction and is apart from having no extinction and nirvana. Having no form is apart from having no form.
Nirvana is the extinction of exhaustion and has nothing to exhaust. All dharmas are tranquil and apart from tranquility. All dharmas
have nothing that is acceptable or unacceptable and do not lose anything. In wisdom, being apart from the basis is not a name and has no thought.ğŸ”½What is illuminated
has nothing to illuminate. In illumination and darkness, there is no one who knows each other. In delusion and wisdom, there is no one who enters each other.
The Way has no one who attains the Way, whether in suffering or happiness, there is no cognition of characteristics. What arises has no
thought. In purity, there is no difficulty or ease. What is crossed over has no master. What is reached is free from characteristics and
separation. All dharmas are neither names nor apart from names. What is crossed over is like flowing water. In names, there is
no turning. Such a one is precisely the Way.

The Buddha uses samÄdhi to cross over like the human mind. With myriad things self-adorned, the adornments are formless. Adornments are for inverted views, adorning all agreeable kings. Adornments are merely thoughts and non-thoughts.
MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« Bodhisattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
How many of the devas and humans who have come to this assembly have attained this samÄdhi?
The Buddha told MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«:

All those in this assembly, devas and humans, have universally attained this samÄdhi and this merit. They will all become Buddhas and will receive the supreme prediction, cutting off the five destinies.

At that time, those in the assembly who heard the Buddha's words, eight thousand koá¹­is of devas and humans, all attained the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas. They rose into the sky three hundred zhang above the ground, and on their bodies were myriad koá¹­is of flowers and fragrances. They then descended and bowed their heads at the Buddha's feet.
The bodhisattvas Ä€lo and HÄti rose from their seats and said to the Buddha:
These superior people are flying in the sky, and the flowers and fragrances on their bodies - where do they come from?
The Buddha said:
It is like a pure silk cloth that is originally clean and pure. Wherever it is dyed, the five colors are fresh and beautiful.
The silk is originally pure, and the colors are also originally pure. It is due to the causes and conditions of the two things that they become bright and beautiful.
The colors do not enter the silk, and the silk does not enter the colors. It is through the pure causes and conditions that they become manifest.
It is the same for the bodhisattvas' purity and the flowers and fragrances they attain.

The bodhisattva is also not in the flowers and fragrances, and the flowers and fragrances do not adhere to the bodhisattva. The gods and humans attain the elimination of thoughts and attain the Dharma of bright wisdom, and then there is the vision of flowers, which arises due to the purity of the flowers as a cause and condition. The Dharma is also like this.

Those who are without abiding accomplish all merits. Those who practice with the thought of abiding open the door to birth and death. The reason why arhats and pratyekabuddhas are far from the five realms is only because of the ten inverted views:
First, seeing all merits and sayings as all inverted views;
Second, seeing the suffering of the five realms and wishing to attain nirvana, this is an inverted view;
Third, seeing that all things are impermanent and wanting to quickly leave them, this is an inverted view;
Fourth, seeking peace that is originally without a basis, this is an inverted view;
Fifth, knowing that leaving is without an interval and entering is without a place, the world itself is without leaving yet seeking it without ceasing, this is an inverted view;

Sixth, when arhats attain nirvana, the fire in their bodies arises by itself, and the fire has no source. They give rise to the thought that the fire in their bodies burns them by themselves. Therefore, they know that birth and death are not severed. This is inverted view.
Seventh, the beginning and end are inexhaustible, yet they seek to end it by themselves. This is inverted view.
Eighth, wishing to extinguish all evils in nirvana, not knowing that there is no master, they wish to extinguish it in reverse. This is inverted view.
Ninth, what is given does not accord with the intentions of all people, but only wishes for the Dharma to be uninterrupted. This is inverted view.
Tenth, in suffering and joy, they practice unequally and say there are two dharmas. This is inverted view.
Those who practice the bodhisattva path should know these things and quickly depart from them.
The Buddha said to Ä€lÅ« Bodhisattva, MÄti Bodhisattva, and others:

Now, all these devas and people in the assembly are people from the time of Buddha Ahanunuo. Those who are now all receiving predictions in front of me have already received this samadhi from 60,000 buddhas in their past lives, and are now being predicted here for that reason.

Later, when my Dharma is about to be cut off, these 400,000 people will uphold the Dharma and keep it from being cut off, and then after a long time there will be evil monks and people who violate the precepts who will destroy my Dharma.
Subhuti said to the Buddha:
Which bodhisattvas protect the Dharma and prevent it from being cut off?
The Buddha told Subhuti:
These 400,000 bodhisattvas all abide below the eighth stage, and the thought of being burdened by the Dharma is what protects and upholds the Dharma and prevents it from being cut off.
Subhuti said to the Buddha:
Who are the destroyers of the Dharma?
Please, Buddha, speak of it.
The Buddha told Subhuti:

If there are those who attain arhatship, pratyekabuddhahood, or become monks or gods and humans, who give rise to thoughts and burdens, seek fame in the Dharma, destroy and confuse their original wisdom, falsely increase and decrease the Dharma, explain it with branches and leaves, confuse the true with the false, confuse the path with eloquence, do not contemplate empty wisdom but strive for adornment, hear that the Buddha can be attained and aspire to transcend and obtain it, do not know skillful means, and do not diligently cultivate meritorious practices, they are Dharma thieves who destroy my path.
The Asura gods, the Panna-ti gods, the Ti-lou-ni gods, the Ku-shu-ti gods, and the Shi-na-li gods all said to the Buddha:
We wish to take refuge in those who uphold the Dharma for the rest of our lives. For thousands, millions, and billions of eons, without rest, may we always attain this samÄdhi.
The Buddha said:
Those who possess virtue and uphold the samÄdhi according to the Dharma without error will quickly attain Buddhahood.

Those who give rise to the intention to practice this samÄdhi are like the treasure in the Heaven of Cessation, the king of all treasures, the most revered treasure in the heavens above and below. This treasure only appears when there is a Buddha in the world, called the precious mani pearl. If one obtains this pearl and holds it in a vessel or in one's hand, looking at it from all four directions, one can wish for it to rain precious treasures for several days, and whatever one desires will be obtained. This revered treasure pearl should not be greedily hoarded, but should rain down on the three realms, enabling all to obtain treasures. The virtue of this samÄdhi is also like this.
The king of RÄjagá¹›ha said to the Buddha:

The Buddha is the revered savior, the great guide of the world, always having great compassion to rescue the ten directions. I wish for the precious pearl to rain down on my kingdom, enabling the people to universally obtain blessings and benefits.
The Buddha then smiled, and a divine light shone brightly.

The Buddha does not smile without reason. I wish to hear the meaning of this.
The Buddha said to Ä€nanda:
Do you see this king?

He wishes to attain nirvÄá¹‡a and the heavenly treasure pearl, to rain down on RÄjagá¹›ha to make it universally prosperous, but he does not know that he has already attained this treasure through the samÄdhi of the coming of the treasure.
The Buddha said to the king:

Do you see the people who have not eaten for a hundred days, yet are universally at ease, taking the Dharma as their flavor? Moreover, all the women have been transformed into men. Are not the benefits of the Dharma great?

The king's heart was delighted. He immediately took off his jeweled necklace and scattered it over the Buddha and the bodhisattvas. It transformed into a flower canopy suspended in the sky, with hundreds of thousands of musical performances in between. The king was doubly elated, forgetting about the thought of eating.
The king said to the Buddha:
Where did this flower canopy come from?
The Buddha said:
It came from nowhere.
He further asked:
Where does nowhere come from?
The Buddha said:
It arises from the unborn.
He further asked:ğŸ”½What is the unborn?

The Buddha said:
It comes from non-birth.
He further asked:
Where does non-birth come from?
The answer was:
It comes from non-movement.
He further asked:
Where does non-movement come from?
The answer was:
It comes from non-creation.
He further asked:
Where does non-creation come from?
He said:
It comes from the nameless.
He further asked:
Where does the nameless come from?
He said:
It comes from non-birth.
He further asked:
Where does non-birth come from?
He said:
It comes from non-sound.
He further asked:
Where does non-sound come from?
He said:
It comes from non-duality.
He further asked:
Where does non-duality come from?
He said:
It comes from shapelessness.
He asked again:
Where does shapelessness come from?
He replied:
It comes from spontaneity.
He asked again:
Where does spontaneity come from?
He replied:
It comes from transformation.
He asked again:
Where does transformation come from?
He replied:
It comes from beyond transformation.
He asked again:
Where does that beyond transformation come from?
He replied:
It comes from the place beyond non-transformation, where there is no conceptual knowledge.
He asked again:
Where does the place beyond conceptual knowledge come from?
The Buddha said:
For this reason, it is the Dharma of all things.
Hearing the Buddha's words, the king was overjoyed and said to the Buddha:
These bodhisattvas have come from afar. I wish to invite them all to my palace tomorrow.
The Buddha immediately accepted the invitation on their behalf.

The king then returned to the palace to adorn the offerings, setting up canopies and banners along the road, and in the palace, seats were made of precious treasures, and the palace ladies observed the precepts with utmost respect.
The next day, Manjushri, Baolai, and the other bodhisattvas all went to the king's palace.
Bodhisattva Baolai yielded to Manjushri, saying:
Now, the most venerable ones should enter first.
The bodhisattvas said:

One who has no abode in wisdom, no form in the mind, no thought in memory, no bestowal in the Dharma, whose bestowal is not apart from the Way, who has already severed the wheel of Dharma, who has no thought of Dharma, whose thoughts have neither much nor little, such a one is therefore venerable and often enters into skillful means, who has no knowledge of the characteristics of all knowledge, who has already donned the armor of the Dharma, whose samadhi has neither increase nor decrease, such a one is venerable and should therefore take the lead.
Bodhisattva Baolai replied:
Now, the elders are of advanced age and great virtue, and therefore they are venerable. They should enter first.
The bodhisattvas said:

Our age is like a withered tree, the roots have already died and there are no flowers or leaves, and we provide little shade for the world. Although you are young, your wisdom is very deep, like a precious tree that greatly benefits the world. Therefore, you are venerable and should enter first.
After they all entered the palace and sat down, the gods above made music to entertain them.
The king had the chief consort and court ladies burn various famous incense and present offerings. After the meal was finished, the king asked RatnÄkara:
I now wish to see the buddhas of the ten directions. What methods should I practice to see them?
RatnÄkara said:
If you wish to see the buddhas, you should practice nine methods:

First, to view the Buddhas of the ten directions as no different from oneself; second, to view the Way as having no path; third, to view all people as having no one who escapes; fourth, to view food as like an illusion; fifth, to know that the five skandhas have no conceptual thoughts; sixth, to know that the six sense faculties are like an illusion when observed; seventh, to know that what is observed is only an inverted view; eighth, to make great offerings within the Dharma; ninth, to know that what is given is nothing given. These are the nine.
Emptying one's mind, viewing equally without distinction, with a tranquil will, attaining pure concentration, and seeing nothing, one universally sees the Buddha.
At that time, he praised RatnÄrcis, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
It is just as you have said.
The Buddha spoke a verse, saying:
Always make this vow, in every life encounter the Honored One,
From him receive great wisdom, always eliminate the roots of desire.
Not greedy and not jealous, evil thoughts do not arise again,
Then from countless Buddhas, one hears this samÄdhi.
Entering the trichiliocosm, always practicing the honored samÄdhi,
Not from all people, all precious treasures.
The Dharma does not come from the five aggregates, nor does it depart from its place,
From contemplation one attains liberation, all are like this.
From contemplation one attains joy, the intention does not arise,
That place is already like this, therefore it is the god among gods.
If in the three realms, one does not give birth nor die,
NirvÄá¹‡a and the two vehicles, all do not have this.
The mind should not have wrong thoughts, what is practiced is non-dharma,
If in the three realms, hold the mind to prevent arising.

All dharmas are also like this.
The names of the buddhas in the trichiliocosm are all like this,
Unheard and unseen, not something to be discussed.

The wise understand this meaning, and attain the impermanence of the Buddha.

Always acting as boundless water, covering the trichiliocosm.
The dhÄraá¹‡Ä« of the mind's aspirations, the intention arises without precedent,
The Dharma is already like this, all should practice it.
I recall when seeking the Dharma, for innumerable eons,
The intention always abandoned the home, not seeking desires.
Always relying on good and wise advisors, establishing the correct Dharma,
At that time, in the great assembly, I heard the honored one's samÄdhi.
All were greatly delighted, and immediately stayed in the sky,
One hundred and forty feet above the ground, with palms joined, by the Buddha's side.
The bodhisattvas sitting now, receiving the prediction, are also like this,
Their minds increase in joy, having heard the various samÄdhis.
Then, from one buddha-land, they fly to the presence of the buddhas,
Without moving or shaking, they quake the realms.
The dragon kings greatly rejoice, and rain down myriad fragrances,
Transforming into various ponds and pools, reaching up to the trichiliocosm.
Flowers and incense naturally come, and a chaotic wind naturally arises,
With a hundred kinds of music, all staying in the sky.
Then the bodhisattva BhadrapÄla asked MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«,
These fragrant flowers coming from other lands, and the various kinds of music coming to the assembly, are they the Buddha's majestic spiritual power?
Or are they the power of the bodhisattvas?ğŸ”½MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« said, It is the power of the bodhisattvas.

The spiritual powers and transformations attained by Buddhas and Bodhisattvas are all invisible. Knowing this joy is nameless joy, with a place of existence.

The Dharma sound is a nameless place. If joy is a joyful place, all that exists is like an illusion, which is joy.ğŸ”½Being without two dharmas is joy. Wishing to deliver all Arhats and Pratyekabuddhas is joy.
Seeing all non-Buddhist paths, wishing to cause them to attain Buddhahood, is joy. The liberated have no master, which is joy.
In all places, there is nothing and nothing arises. Being free from burden in samÄdhi is joy. In all places,
there is no name, which is joy. All that exists is like an illusion, which is joy. The non-sound place is the unborn place,
which is joy. The Dharma given is ungiven, which is joy. In the trichiliocosm, there is no permanent place,
which is joy. Causing all people to attain faith without attainment is joy. In the future, passing
To go to the three places of the present and end without ending is bliss. To make one return to the original and see nothing is bliss.
To see the Dharma wheel is to see nothing, which is bliss. To be equal to all in the trichiliocosm is bliss.
The Dharma treasury of the ten directions and the trichiliocosm is bliss. The lands of the ten directions are merely names, which is bliss.

The union of form and desire is bliss. There is no master in names and words, which is bliss.ğŸ”½The boundless peace of all is bliss. The union of all light and darkness is bliss. Not losing precepts in all practices is bliss.
Not leaving samÄdhi in all thoughts is bliss. The boundless perfection of the treasure of space is bliss.

To make all light shine again is bliss. All that exists is merely inverted views.
Seeing the correct is happiness, giving without expectation is happiness, the mind is without extreme action
The great ship captain is happiness, the boundless garden liberation is happiness, the mind is tranquil and still is happiness
Having nothing fixed is happiness, the various samÄdhi gates are without inversion is happiness, there is neither listening
Nor hearing is happiness, all thoughts are not the correct mind is happiness, all people are without liberation

Happiness, the bodhisattvas come from nowhere is happiness, the bodhisattvas are born in the mind
And reach the ten directions is happiness, not blue, yellow, white, or black, without a path is happiness.
Thus, RatnÄrcis!
If you wish to know the music and happiness of the Buddha and bodhisattvas' majestic spirit, it is like this.
Bodhisattva RatnÄrcis spoke a verse, saying:
The mind of MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«, the wise and venerable one, is without precedent,
The offerings made to the three thousand, whose wisdom is not revered.

The offerings of Dharma joy given, if empty there are no liberated ones.
Dharma joy practiced together, there is no treasure that surpasses this,
The joy is without a master, if empty there is no location.
Deeply entering the subtle, understanding all people,
Causing them to attain the great Dharma, cutting off the roots of suffering.
All the people in the world, all have minds that do not understand,
Using the Dharma as the enlightened mind, using wisdom to save all.
At that time the Buddha spoke a verse from afar for the Bodhisattva Jewel-Come:
Apart from emptiness, non-thought is thought, not emptiness. Not giving rise to dharmas,
is precisely giving rise to them.
One should always have a gentle mind, pure and without anything, with form and desire united, without characteristics entering.
What is said to be formless is not apart from form. Dharmas are like a dream, with nothing that can be reached.
This is quiescence apart from quiescence, without separation or creation. The myriad dharmas have no master,
what can be attained is like a transformation.
There is nothing at all that is received, the Dharma has nothing to discard. What is done reaches seeing, all are thus.
Not form, apart from form, this form is not apart from, its Dharma is like form, its place is thus.
Not sound is echo, without hearing or seeing, not listening or observing,
what exists is thus.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
In transformation, there is no name, yet one says it is so. The Dharma is not so-called, and those to be liberated are like this.
In illusion, there is no seeing, and what is seen is apart from seeing. Apart from craving and desires, the Dharma is not what is relied upon.
In desires, there is no defilement, and there is no attachment or separation. Such is the true seeing,
yet there is no one who sees.
In purity, there is separation from purity. In the ten directions, there is no creation. What can be real is like a transformation without a master.
Bodhisattva Ratnasaá¹ƒbhava, knowing what the Buddha had said, then spoke a verse in the palace:
Suspecting the basis to be incomprehensible, considering the Dharma to be so. Originally, there is no permanence,
Suspicion and wisdom are like this.
In conceptualization, there is no toil. In consciousness and recollection, there is no suffering. Utterance and abiding in words are not for one who seeks the Dharma.
In the original, it is not so, not returning is not so, what can be is nothing, far from nothing.
If birth is free from extinction, that is extinction, in extinction there is no thought,
this is not extinction.
In the Dharma there is no arising, nor is it thought to be accomplished, why is it so?
All dharmas are empty.
I also do not seek to say that I am apart from nirvana, why is it so?
Because the beginning and end are pure.
Not exhausting the ten directions, taking it as a testimony, saying this is me,
this is then a testimony.
One should not think of the ten directions from afar, the Dharma is non-dual, and one then attains the nameless.
The Dharma is not something that can be attained through thought, if one practices like this, one does not see the sublime Dharma.
One must understand wisdom, not being afraid of the sublime, deeply practicing without being the master,
Can be called the gate of wisdom.
Bodhisattva Baolai asked Manjushri:
For those who have newly given rise to the intention in this assembly, if I wish to enable them to attain the ultimate Dharma, how should I do so?
Manjushri replied:
In non-action within thoughts, one can attain the ultimate Dharma.
He further asked:
What is meant by non-action within thoughts?
Manjushri said:
One should attain the nine Dharma treasures:

First, the mind has no abode, this is a treasure; second, contemplating the Dharma has no master, this is a treasure; third, not seeing the future or past, this is a treasure; fourth, in the Dharma there is no creator, this is a treasure; fifth, what is given is only given to the Dharma, this is a treasure; sixth, seeing the suffering of the five paths and not turning away from them, this is a treasure; seventh, what is realized is not far from skillful means, this is a treasure; eighth, directly seeing all dharmas without abiding in the duality of dharmas, this is a treasure; ninth, attaining nirvana is also like an illusion, this is a treasure. These are the nine Dharma treasures.
Then MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« spoke a verse, saying:
In what is possible, there is nothing desired; the abode has no permanent name.
If it is empty and without defilement, the Buddha's smile is without impossibility.
The smile is empty and not apart from the end; as it was originally, there was no one who smiled.
Already abiding in the name of all dharmas, everything is like a smile.
The beginning and end are all natural, with no coming and going,
Those who laugh have retribution to return, but do not return, nor do they laugh.
The Dharma is all one, but having laughed, there are two,
In two there are no names, therefore it is the Honored One.
What is laughed at is unattached, but it is for the Dharma's giving,
What moves is unmoved, therefore it is the unsurpassed Honored One.
What is laughed at has no retribution to return, and all have no master,
What is laughed at does not depart from the origin, therefore it is the Heaven among Heavens.
What is laughed at has no arising, but is only for inverted views,
In the Dharma, all are tranquil, because tranquility is originally non-existent.
What is laughed at does not depart from transformation, using transformation for great giving,
In transformation, there is no name to be raised, therefore it is the Dharma.
In the Dharma, there is no suchness, but it is only for giving without liberation,
Those who are liberated are not liberated, and the Buddha is also like this.
Therefore, in the great assembly, discussing liberation and non-liberation,
In the Dharma, making offerings, there is no one who can compare.
ÅšÄriputra asked Baolai:
You want to make all learners in the ten directions attain the dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s of all dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s.
What Dharma should they practice to attain it?
Baolai said:
They should practice the thirty-two Dharma treasures:
First, wanting to make all those who have not yet given rise to the intention to attain enlightenment all transcend it like a transformation without obstruction;
Second, those who have not given rise to the intention for the unsurpassed true Way all make them abide in the right Dharma;
Third, viewing the trichiliocosm equally without distinction;
Fourth, if abiding in limits, causing them to be far removed from various desires and in the gate of wisdom, without movement or change, attaining nirvÄá¹‡a;

Seventh, one views the present and future without duality, as there is no coming or rebirth;
Eighth, one observes all samÄdhis and dhyÄnas as tranquil and without location;
Ninth, all that is to be liberated has no master, as everything comes from emptiness and returns to emptiness;
Tenth, I have received the Dharma from all Buddhas in the trichiliocosm;
Eleventh, those who come from other lands to listen to the sÅ«tras will all attain certainty;
Twelfth, I neither delight in the flowers and incense of all Buddha lands that come, nor seek them if they do not come;
Thirteenth, I wish for all who give rise to the intention to attain the abiding of the Dharma;
Fourteenth, my mind does not increase or decrease with regard to the future and past, why is this?
Because I know the fundamental non-duality;
Fifteenth, I wish for all sentient beings in the ten directions, including those that crawl and slither, to uphold the precepts without ever violating them;
Sixteenth, having no wrong thoughts towards the ten directions, turning the mind back to the origin is to face the gate of wisdom;
Seventeenth, having nothing that cannot be endured, always without wrong resentment;
Eighteenth, from contemplation to contemplation, there is no one who can cross over;
Nineteenth, like the original non-abiding, there is no place of permanent abiding;
Twentieth, what is crossed over has no master, like empty space without thoughts or concepts;
Twenty-first, in wisdom, giving without any name to lift up, not attached to desires, then liberation is attained from this;
Twenty-second, what is said does not depart from giving based on causes and conditions;
In the great assembly of the country, there is no one who can cross over and be liberated;
Twenty-third, in countless lands, flying to other lands, in front of the buddhas, without any obstruction;
Twenty-fourth, looking at all lands as equal, there is no one who can cross over and be liberated;
Twenty-fifth, purifying delusion, merging with the original purity, without difference;
Twenty-sixth, dwelling in the great trichiliocosm, acting as a bridge, encouraging the unenlightened to follow the dark and see the light;

Twenty-ninth, acting as inexhaustible wisdom, not leaving the ten directions;
Thirtieth, acting with great compassion, nurturing all, all those not yet liberated will be liberated, thus called the god among gods;
Thirty-first, always practicing impartial mind, without partiality, saving and delivering without compare, thus called the unsurpassed honored one;
Thirty-second, the teachings of the bodhisattvas do not depart from the scriptures, heard equally throughout the great trichiliocosm, therefore flowers naturally appear in the sky;
These are the thirty-two Dharma treasures of the bodhisattvas.
Then Bodhisattva Ratnasaá¹ƒbhava spoke a verse, saying:
The ten directions are all like transformations, everything is impermanent,
The true Dharma is the correct and tranquil truth, expounding it to liberate sentient beings,
Having thoughts is not apart from thoughts, everything is originally empty,
If flowers are not yet offered, their color cannot be compared,
All the desires of the multitude, establishing them as the king of intentions,
The unsurpassed honored one among all treasures, called the god among gods.
